questions.text:
A patient presented with complaints of rashes over both his legs. The rashes evolved as shown in the picture below:

The patient's condition was deteriorating. On examination the patient had cold skin and bluish tinge on fingernails. The vitals of patient were:
PR: 98/min
BP: 100/58
RR: 24/min
Along With this, the urine output of patients was reduced to 200ml in 12 hours and patients' S.creatinine was increased to 7.9 mg/dL. Eventually the patient became disoriented with time, place and person and his respiratory distress worsened.
Which of the following statements are true for the organism causing these symptoms in the patient?
1) The causative organism is capsulated.
2) It is kidney shaped.
3) It ferments only glucose.
4) Its habitat is nasopharynx.
5) It exists only in intracellular form.
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The image in question shows purpura fulminans. Purpura fulminans, along with shock-like symptoms and kidney failure(MODS), indicates that the patient has Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which is a capsulated bacterium that colonizes the nasopharynx.

  • The clinical picture shows a rapidly progressing purpuric rash evolving into hemorrhagic necrosis, along with systemic deterioration-hypotension, oliguria, raised serum creatinine, respiratory distress, and confusion.
  • These features are highly suggestive of Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome, a fulminant and often fatal complication of meningococcemia.
  • Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is characterised by:
    • Septicemia with Neisseria meningitidis
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
    • Adrenal gland haemorrhage and acute adrenal insufficiency
    • Multiorgan failure and shock
    • The underlying organism is Neisseria meningitidis, a Gram-negative diplococcus responsible for meningococcemia and meningitis.
  • Important microbiological features include:
    • Capsule: The organism is encapsulated, and the polysaccharide capsule is its major virulence factor. It prevents phagocytosis and allows bloodstream survival. This capsule forms the basis for serogroup classification (e.g., A, B, C, Y, W135).
    • Nasopharyngeal habitat: The human nasopharynx is the natural reservoir. Asymptomatic colonisation is common, and transmission occurs through respiratory droplets.
    • Pathogenesis: When it invades the bloodstream, the endotoxin (lipooligosaccharide) induces massive cytokine release, endothelial damage, DIC, and adrenal haemorrhage, leading to Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.
  • Thus, statements 1 (encapsulated) and 4 (nasopharynx as habitat) are both true.
  • It is kidney-shaped: Incorrect. This is a feature of Leptospira, a spirochete, not Neisseria.
  • It ferments only glucose: Incorrect. Neisseria meningitidis ferments both glucose and maltose.
  • It exists only in intracellular form: Incorrect. Neisseria can be seen both intra- and extracellularly; exclusively intracellular behaviour is typical of Chlamydia.

questions.text:
A patient presented with rashes on his body. The rashes were non-blanching on examination.

The gram staining shows the following picture.

Which of the following culture media is used to isolate the possible organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Thayer-Martin medium is a selective medium used for the isolation of Neisseria species, especially Neisseria meningitidis, from clinical specimens.

  • The clinical presentation of non-blanching petechial or purpuric rash, often progressing rapidly and associated with systemic symptoms, points toward meningococcemia, which is caused by Neisseria meningitidis.
  • The Gram stain provided in the image shows Gram-negative kidney-shaped diplococci, typically seen within neutrophils-;characteristic of Neisseria species.
  • Neisseria species are fastidious organisms requiring enriched and selective media for growth.
  • The Thayer-Martin medium is a chocolate agar base supplemented with antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim) to inhibit the growth of contaminating flora:
    • Vancomycin: inhibits Gram-positive bacteria
    • Colistin: inhibits Gram-negative rods
    • Nystatin: inhibits fungi
    • Trimethoprim: inhibits swarming Proteus spp.
  • This makes Thayer-Martin medium ideal for isolating Neisseria meningitidis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae from sites like the nasopharynx, genital tract, or blood.
  • Thayer Martin medium is also known as the New York City medium.

Explanation of other options:

Sabouraud agar (Option A): This is a selective medium used for fungal culture, especially dermatophytes and yeasts. It is not used to grow Neisseria species.

MacConkey agar (Option B): It is selective for enteric Gram-negative bacilli, such as E. coli and Klebsiella. Neisseria meningitidis does not grow on this medium.

Deoxycholate citrate agar (Option D): This medium is used to isolate Salmonella and Shigella from stool samples. It is not suitable for fastidious organisms like Neisseria.

questions.text:
Identify the cause of urethritis in the above image:

A.
B.
C.
D.
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The image shows urethral discharge, and the stained smear in image A reveals intracellular gram-negative diplococci within neutrophils. This is pathognomonic for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus that infects mucosal surfaces, particularly the urethra, and causes purulent urethritis.
  • It characteristically appears as pink (gram-negative), kidney-shaped diplococci located inside polymorphonuclear leukocytes (neutrophils) on Gram stain - exactly as seen in image A.
  • This makes N. gonorrhoeae the most likely cause of urethritis in this case.
  • For Gonorrhea:
    • Urethral swabs in men and cervical swabs in women are the preferred specimens.
    • Vaginal swab is not satisfactory.
    • The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
    • The urethral meatus is cleaned with gauze soaked in saline. The purulent discharge is expressed by pressing at the base of the penis and collected directly onto slides or swabs.
    • Dacron or rayon swabs are preferred, as cotton alginate swabs are inhibitory to gonococci.
    • In chronic urethritis, as discharge is minimal, prostate massage is done to collect the secretion; alternatively, the morning drop of secretion may be collected.
    • Transport media: Stuarts and Amies transport medium.

Comparison between Gonococcal and Non-gonococcal Urethritis:


Explanation of other options:

Option B: Shows Trichomonas vaginalis, a motile protozoan seen in wet mount microscopy. It causes vaginitis, not typically purulent urethritis with intracellular gram-negative diplococci.

Option C: Although it appears similar to Image A, it may be a duplicate or a less clear example. Still, based on clarity and classic appearance, Image A better fits N. gonorrhoeae. Image C is thus not the best choice.

Option D: Shows inclusion bodies within epithelial cells, consistent with Chlamydia trachomatis, which causes non-gonococcal urethritis. However, Chlamydia is not seen on Gram stain and appears as intracytoplasmic basophilic inclusions on Giemsa stain or with DFA, not like what's shown in image A.

questions.text: Meningococcal vaccine is ineffective against which of the following serogroups?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The meningococcal vaccine is ineffective against serogroup B due to the poor immunogenicity of its polysaccharide capsule, which mimics human neural cell adhesion molecules.

  • Meningococcal vaccines are designed to target the polysaccharide capsules of different Neisseria meningitidis serogroups, the most common being A, B, C, W135, and Y.
  • These capsules are the main virulence factors and are used as antigens in vaccine formulations.
  • Polysaccharide-based and conjugate vaccines are available for serogroups A, C, W135, and Y.
  • However, serogroup B is not effectively covered by traditional vaccines because its polysaccharide capsule is made of polysialic acid, which closely resembles human neural cell adhesion molecules.
  • This molecular mimicry results in:
    • Poor immune response (low immunogenicity)
    • Risk of autoimmunity if used in vaccines
  • Due to this, vaccines targeting serogroup B require non-capsular antigens, such as outer membrane proteins.
  • These newer protein-based vaccines (e.g., 4CMenB, also called Bexsero) are now available in some countries but were not part of the original polysaccharide or quadrivalent conjugate vaccines.
  • Thus, traditional meningococcal vaccines do not provide effective protection against serogroup B.

Explanation of other options:

Serogroup A (Option A): Covered by both polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines; included in the quadrivalent vaccine (MenACWY).

Serogroup C (Option C): Effectively targeted by both monovalent and quadrivalent conjugate vaccines.

Serogroup W135 (Option D): Also included in the quadrivalent MenACWY vaccine formulations.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old girl presents with a 3-day history of fever, pruritic rash, and bilateral ankle pain and swelling associated with difficulty walking. On arrival, she had a fever of 101.4°F. A rash is present on her lower legs, feet, and her fingers. Her left ankle has diffuse swelling, warmth, redness, tenderness, and a limited range of motion.

After detailed workup, the patient was found to have disseminated gonococcal infection. What is the drug of choice for the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice for disseminated gonococcal infection.

  • This presentation - fever, tenosynovitis, migratory polyarthritis, and pustular rash - is classic for disseminated gonococcal infection, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • It often affects young, sexually active individuals and may present with joint pain, rash, and fever even in the absence of urogenital symptoms.
  • Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice, which is a third-generation cephalosporin that:
    • Covers Neisseria gonorrhoeae effectively
    • Penetrates joint spaces
    • It is recommended by the CDC for DGI
  • Typical regimen:
    • Ceftriaxone 1g IV/IM daily + azithromycin or doxycycline for concurrent Chlamydia trachomatis coverage.

Explanation of other options:

Ceftazidime (Option A): Active against Pseudomonas, but not the first-line drug for gonococcal infections.

Cefotaxime (Option C): Similar spectrum to ceftriaxone, but ceftriaxone has superior pharmacokinetics and is preferred in gonococcal infections.

Cefazolin (Option D): First-generation cephalosporin. Good for gram-positive cocci (like MSSA), but not reliable for N. gonorrhoeae.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge and pain. A Gram stain of her cervical swab shows Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear cells. What is the best next step for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Thayer-Martin agar is a selective medium used to culture Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which appears as Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear cells.

  • The Gram stain showing Gram-negative diplococci inside PMNs is highly suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, culture on Thayer-Martin agar is the best next step.
  • Thayer-Martin medium contains antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim) that suppress the growth of commensal flora while allowing Neisseria gonorrhoeae to grow.
  • It is a gold standard for gonococcal culture and helps in antimicrobial susceptibility testing.
  • Although nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are also used for N. gonorrhoeae, this question specifically asks for the best next step following a suggestive Gram stain, making culture on selective media the most appropriate to confirm identity and allow for susceptibility testing, particularly in symptomatic cases.

Explanation of other options:

Perform a PCR test for Chlamydia trachomatis (Option A): Chlamydia trachomatis is an intracellular bacterium that does not appear on a Gram stain and is not the likely organism given the findings. It may be tested in parallel, but not the best next step here.

Send the specimen for culture on Sabouraud agar (Option C): Sabouraud agar is used for fungal cultures, not for bacterial pathogens like Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Perform a rapid antigen test for Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option D): There is no widely validated rapid antigen test for N. gonorrhoeae; such tests lack sensitivity and specificity compared to culture or NAATs.

questions.text:
A 2nd year MBBS student was doing research on what components of the immune system are infected in various infections causing meningitis. In one of the patients, Gram staining showed the following:

Which component of the immune system is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Deficiency in the terminal complement pathway (especially C5-C9) predisposes individuals to recurrent Neisseria meningitidis infections.

  • The presence of Gram-negative diplococci on a Gram stain suggests Neisseria meningitidis, a major cause of bacterial meningitis.
  • Patients with terminal complement deficiencies (C5, C6, C7, C8, or C9) are particularly susceptible to infections by encapsulated Neisseria species, as the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system is crucial for lysis of these bacteria.
  • Such individuals often present with recurrent meningococcal infections, especially in the absence of other immune defects.
  • Testing complement activity (CH50 assay) is commonly used to assess the integrity of the classical pathway and MAC formation.

Explanation of other options:

B lymphocytes (Option A): B-cell deficiencies increase susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria in general, but they don't specifically predispose to Neisseria infections like complement deficiencies do.

Defective phagocytosis (Option C): Phagocytic defects (e.g., CGD) typically predispose to catalase-positive organisms, not Neisseria.

Defective antibody synthesis (Option D): Hypogammaglobulinemia leads to broad susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria, but terminal complement deficiency has a stronger association with Neisseria meningitidis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative organism of the given clinical presentation in the patient visiting the Ophthalmology OPD?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Moraxella lacunata is the classical cause of angular conjunctivitis, particularly seen in elderly or debilitated patients.

  • The clinical image shows signs of angular blepharoconjunctivitis, a condition characterised by:
    • Irritation and redness around the medial canthus
    • Purulent discharge, typically crusting at the angles of the eye
    • Possible fissuring or maceration of the eyelid skin
  • The most likely causative agent is Moraxella lacunata, a Gram-negative diplobacillus, known for causing angular conjunctivitis.
  • It is a normal commensal of the conjunctiva but becomes pathogenic under certain conditions, especially in the elderly, immunocompromised, or malnourished patients. It presents with a localized infection at the canthi, with mucopurulent discharge and conjunctival injection, findings evident in the image.
  • Unlike other causes of conjunctivitis, angular conjunctivitis due to M. lacunata affects the skin around the medial canthus due to the irritating nature of the discharge, leading to skin breakdown and tenderness.

Explanation of other options:

Moraxella catarrhalis (Option B): Primarily a pathogen of the respiratory tract, causing sinusitis, otitis media, and bronchitis. It is not known to cause conjunctivitis.

Moraxella osloensis (Option C): A rare human pathogen, sometimes isolated in immunocompromised individuals. No established association with conjunctivitis.

Moraxella urethralis (Option D): Found in the urogenital tract, potentially linked to urethritis. Not implicated in eye infections.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1706007/

choices.text: DNAse and tributyrin hydrolysis is positive for Neisseria
Only DNAse is positive for Neisseria
Only DNAse is positive for moraxella
DNAse and tributyrin hydrolysis is positive for Moraxella

questions.text: There is a slide of Gram negative diplococci under the microscope. The attending microbiologist asks you to differentiate gram negative diplococci: Neisseria and moraxella on the basis of biochemical properties. Which of the following would be your correct answer?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Moraxella species are distinguished from Neisseria by their positive DNase activity and ability to hydrolyse tributyrin, which Neisseria cannot do.

  • Both Neisseria and Moraxella are gram-negative diplococci, often appearing morphologically similar under microscopy, making biochemical differentiation essential in the laboratory setting.
  • To differentiate them, the following biochemical tests are used:
    • DNAse test:
      • Moraxella (especially Moraxella catarrhalis) is DNAse-positive, meaning it can hydrolyse DNA on DNAse agar.
      • In contrast, Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis are DNase-negative.
    • Tributyrin hydrolysis test:
      • This test detects butyrate esterase activity.
      • Moraxella catarrhalis is positive, hydrolyzing tributyrin and producing a clear zone.
      • Neisseria species are tributyrin-negative.
    • These tests are crucial in a diagnostic setting, especially in respiratory or ocular infections, where misidentifying Moraxella catarrhalis as Neisseria gonorrhoeae (a notifiable STI pathogen) can have major clinical and public health implications.

Explanation of other options:

DNAse and tributyrin hydrolysis are positive for Neisseria (Option A): Incorrect - Neisseria species are negative for both DNAse and tributyrin hydrolysis.

Only DNAse is positive for Neisseria (Option B): Incorrect - Neisseria is DNAse-negative.

Only DNAse is positive for Moraxella (Option C): Incorrect - While DNAse is positive, Moraxella is also positive for tributyrin hydrolysis, so both are positive.

Reference:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7650/

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a sudden high fever, vomiting, and a petechial rash. On examination, the child is irritable and has a positive Brudzinski sign. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows elevated white blood cells, low glucose, and elevated protein. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The presence of petechial rash along with signs of meningitis strongly suggests meningococcal meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

  • The child presents with signs of acute bacterial meningitis (fever, vomiting, neck stiffness-positive Brudzinski sign) and a petechial rash, which is a classic clinical hallmark of Neisseria meningitidis infection.
  • This Gram-negative diplococcus can cause meningococcemia, which is characterised by sepsis and a petechial or purpuric rash due to small-vessel thrombosis and haemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome).
  • The rash can evolve rapidly and is a distinguishing feature from other causes of meningitis.
  • CSF findings support bacterial meningitis:
    • CSF findings support bacterial meningitis:
    • Elevated WBCs (neutrophilic predominance),
    • Low glucose (due to bacterial consumption),
    • High protein (due to increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier).
  • Meningococcal meningitis is most common in children and young adults, especially in close-contact environments like schools or dormitories.

CSF findings in meningitis:

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A): Most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults; however, it usually does not cause petechial rash.

Haemophilus influenzae (Option B): A cause of meningitis in children, especially before widespread vaccination; rash is not a typical feature.

Enterovirus (Option D): A common cause of viral (aseptic) meningitis; typically presents with normal glucose and no petechial rash.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student is diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. The patient is being treated in the hospital, and public health authorities are concerned about possible transmission to close contacts. Which of the following is the most appropriate chemoprophylaxis for close contacts of the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Ciprofloxacin is the preferred single-dose oral chemoprophylaxis for adult close contacts of meningococcal meningitis patients.

  • Meningococcal meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis is highly contagious and spreads through respiratory droplets.
  • Close contacts-such as roommates, family members, or anyone with prolonged exposure-are at high risk of acquiring the infection.
  • Chemoprophylaxis is essential to prevent secondary cases.
  • Ciprofloxacin (500 mg orally, single dose) is the most commonly recommended prophylactic agent in adults due to:
    • Ease of administration (single oral dose)
    • High efficacy in eradicating nasopharyngeal carriage of N. meningitidis
    • Good tolerability
  • It is the drug of choice for adults unless contraindicated (e.g., pregnancy, resistance concerns).

Explanation of other options:

Azithromycin (Option A): Although azithromycin has been studied for prophylaxis, it is not routinely recommended due to variable efficacy and limited data.

Rifampin (Option C): Effective and used in children and pregnant women, but requires multiple doses (600 mg twice daily for 2 days in adults), which reduces compliance compared to ciprofloxacin.

Penicillin (Option D): Effective for treatment, but not for eradication of nasopharyngeal carriage; hence, not recommended for chemoprophylaxis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active male presents to the STD clinic with complaints of purulent urethral discharge and dysuria for the past 3 days. Gram stain of the urethral exudate reveals numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes with intracellular Gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following virulence factors most significantly contributes to this organism's ability to evade the host immune response?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The organism is Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It evades the host immune system primarily through pili-mediated attachment and antigenic variation, allowing persistence and repeated infections.

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus responsible for the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhea.
  • A hallmark of its pathogenesis is its ability to persist in the host despite an immune response, which it achieves through multiple virulence factors, the most important being:
    • Type IV pili (fimbriae):
      • These allow initial adhesion to the mucosal epithelium, essential for colonization of the urethra, cervix, rectum, or pharynx.
    • Antigenic variation of pili and outer membrane proteins (e.g., Opa proteins):
      • These structures undergo phase and antigenic variation, which prevents effective immune memory formation. Hence, reinfection is common despite prior exposure.
    • This immune evasion is why no effective long-term immunity develops, and why vaccine development has been extremely difficult.

Explanation of other options:

Capsule production (Option A): Unlike Neisseria meningitidis, N. gonorrhoeae does not produce a polysaccharide capsule, making this an incorrect option.

Spore formation (Option C): N. gonorrhoeae is a non-spore-forming bacterium; spore formation is seen in organisms like Clostridium or Bacillus species.

Exotoxin production (Option D): N. gonorrhoeae does not produce classical exotoxins. Its pathogenic effects are primarily due to lipooligosaccharide (LOS)-induced inflammation and immune evasion, not secreted toxins.
